1. Introduction and Motivation

Differential calculus deals with the local rate of change of functions. It is a fundamental tool in analysis and has applications in many areas of mathematics and natural sciences.

What is a Derivative?

The derivative of a function f at point x‚ÇÄ describes the instantaneous rate of change of the function at that point. It indicates how steep the function is at this point.

Intuitively, the derivative can be thought of as the slope of the tangent to the function graph at the point x‚ÇÄ, f(x‚ÇÄ).

2. Definition and Basic Concepts

Definition of the Derivative

The derivative of a function f: D ‚Üí ‚Ñù at point x‚ÇÄ is defined as:

$$f'(x_0) = \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{f(x_0 + h) - f(x_0)}{h}$$

Alternative notations: f'(x‚ÇÄ), df/dx|x‚ÇÄ, d/dx f(x‚ÇÄ)

The derivative exists if and only if the limit exists and is finite.

Examples of Derivatives

1. Derivative of the function f(x) = x¬≤ at the point x‚ÇÄ = 2:

$$f'(2) = \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{(2 + h)^2 - 2^2}{h} = \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{4 + 4h + h^2 - 4}{h} = \lim_{h \to 0} (4 + h) = 4$$

Proof: For Œµ > 0 choose Œ¥ = Œµ. Then for |h| < Œ¥:

$$|(4 + h) - 4| = |h| < \delta = \epsilon$$

2. Derivative of the function f(x) = sin(x) at the point x‚ÇÄ = 0:

$$f'(0) = \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{\sin(h) - \sin(0)}{h} = \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{\sin(h)}{h} = 1$$

Proof: For |h| < œÄ/2 we have:

$$\cos(h) < \frac{\sin(h)}{h} < 1$$

Using the Sandwich Theorem, the claim follows.

3. Derivative of the function f(x) = eÀ£ at the point x‚ÇÄ = 0:

$$f'(0) = \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{e^h - e^0}{h} = \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{e^h - 1}{h} = 1$$

Proof: For h > 0 we have:

$$1 + h < e^h < 1 + h + h^2$$

From this follows:

$$1 < \frac{e^h - 1}{h} < 1 + h$$

Using the Sandwich Theorem, the claim follows.

Important Differentiation Rules

1. Sum Rule

If f and g are differentiable at the point x‚ÇÄ, then:

$$(f + g)'(x_0) = f'(x_0) + g'(x_0)$$

Proof: Follows directly from the definition of the derivative and limit theorems.

Example: (x¬≤ + sin(x))' = 2x + cos(x)

2. Product Rule

If f and g are differentiable at the point x‚ÇÄ, then:

$$(f \cdot g)'(x_0) = f'(x_0) \cdot g(x_0) + f(x_0) \cdot g'(x_0)$$

Proof: From the definition of the derivative follows:

$$(f \cdot g)'(x_0) = \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{f(x_0 + h)g(x_0 + h) - f(x_0)g(x_0)}{h}$$

$$= \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{f(x_0 + h)g(x_0 + h) - f(x_0)g(x_0 + h) + f(x_0)g(x_0 + h) - f(x_0)g(x_0)}{h}$$

$$= \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{f(x_0 + h) - f(x_0)}{h} \cdot g(x_0 + h) + f(x_0) \cdot \frac{g(x_0 + h) - g(x_0)}{h}$$

$$= f'(x_0) \cdot g(x_0) + f(x_0) \cdot g'(x_0)$$

Example: (x ¬∑ sin(x))' = 1 ¬∑ sin(x) + x ¬∑ cos(x)

3. Quotient Rule

If f and g are differentiable at the point x‚ÇÄ and g(x‚ÇÄ) ‚â† 0, then:

$$\left(\frac{f}{g}\right)'(x_0) = \frac{f'(x_0) \cdot g(x_0) - f(x_0) \cdot g'(x_0)}{g(x_0)^2}$$

Proof: From the definition of the derivative follows:

$$\left(\frac{f}{g}\right)'(x_0) = \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{\frac{f(x_0 + h)}{g(x_0 + h)} - \frac{f(x_0)}{g(x_0)}}{h}$$

$$= \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{f(x_0 + h)g(x_0) - f(x_0)g(x_0 + h)}{h \cdot g(x_0 + h)g(x_0)}$$

$$= \frac{f'(x_0)g(x_0) - f(x_0)g'(x_0)}{g(x_0)^2}$$

Example: (sin(x)/x)' = (cos(x) ¬∑ x - sin(x) ¬∑ 1)/x¬≤

4. Chain Rule

If f and g are differentiable and g(x‚ÇÄ) is in the domain of f, then:

$$(f \circ g)'(x_0) = f'(g(x_0)) \cdot g'(x_0)$$

Proof: From the definition of the derivative follows:

$$(f \circ g)'(x_0) = \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{f(g(x_0 + h)) - f(g(x_0))}{h}$$

$$= \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{f(g(x_0 + h)) - f(g(x_0))}{g(x_0 + h) - g(x_0)} \cdot \frac{g(x_0 + h) - g(x_0)}{h}$$

$$= f'(g(x_0)) \cdot g'(x_0)$$

Example: (sin(x¬≤))' = cos(x¬≤) ¬∑ 2x

3. Higher Derivatives

Definition of Higher Derivatives

The n-th derivative of a function f is defined as:

$$f^{(n)}(x) = \frac{d^n}{dx^n} f(x) = \frac{d}{dx} f^{(n-1)}(x)$$

Notations: f^(n)(x), d‚Åøf/dx‚Åø(x)

The n-th derivative describes the rate of change of the (n-1)-th derivative.

Examples of Higher Derivatives

1. Higher derivatives of f(x) = x¬≥:

$$f'(x) = 3x^2, \quad f''(x) = 6x, \quad f'''(x) = 6, \quad f^{(4)}(x) = 0$$

Proof: By repeated application of the differentiation rules.

2. Higher derivatives of f(x) = sin(x):

$$f'(x) = \cos(x), \quad f''(x) = -\sin(x), \quad f'''(x) = -\cos(x), \quad f^{(4)}(x) = \sin(x)$$

Proof: By repeated application of the differentiation rules and trigonometric identities.

3. Higher derivatives of f(x) = eÀ£:

$$f'(x) = e^x, \quad f''(x) = e^x, \quad f'''(x) = e^x, \quad f^{(n)}(x) = e^x$$

Proof: By mathematical induction.

4. Applications

4.1 Extrema

A function f has a local maximum/minimum at the point x‚ÇÄ if f'(x‚ÇÄ) = 0 and f''(x‚ÇÄ) < 0/f''(x‚ÇÄ) > 0.

Example: Find the extrema of f(x) = x¬≥ - 3x

$$f'(x) = 3x^2 - 3 = 0 \Rightarrow x = \pm 1$$

$$f''(x) = 6x \Rightarrow f''(1) = 6 > 0, \quad f''(-1) = -6 < 0$$

Therefore, f has a local minimum at x = 1 and a local maximum at x = -1.

Proof: For x = 1, we have f'(1) = 0 and f''(1) > 0, so f'(x) < 0 for x < 1 and f'(x) > 0 for x > 1. Therefore, f has a local minimum at x = 1.

Similarly for x = -1.

4.2 Monotonicity

A function f is monotonically increasing/decreasing in an interval I if f'(x) ‚â• 0/f'(x) ‚â§ 0 for all x ‚àà I.

Example: Examine the monotonicity of f(x) = x¬≤

$$f'(x) = 2x \begin{cases} > 0 & \text{for } x > 0 \\ < 0 & \text{for } x < 0 \end{cases}$$

Therefore, f is monotonically decreasing for x < 0 and monotonically increasing for x > 0.

Proof: For x‚ÇÅ, x‚ÇÇ with x‚ÇÅ < x‚ÇÇ we have:

$$f(x_2) - f(x_1) = x_2^2 - x_1^2 = (x_2 - x_1)(x_2 + x_1)$$

If x‚ÇÅ, x‚ÇÇ < 0, then x‚ÇÇ + x‚ÇÅ < 0, so f(x‚ÇÇ) - f(x‚ÇÅ) < 0.

If x‚ÇÅ, x‚ÇÇ > 0, then x‚ÇÇ + x‚ÇÅ > 0, so f(x‚ÇÇ) - f(x‚ÇÅ) > 0.

4.3 Curvature

A function f is convex/concave in an interval I if f''(x) ‚â• 0/f''(x) ‚â§ 0 for all x ‚àà I.

Example: Examine the curvature of f(x) = x¬≥

$$f''(x) = 6x \begin{cases} > 0 & \text{for } x > 0 \\ < 0 & \text{for } x < 0 \end{cases}$$

Therefore, f is concave for x < 0 and convex for x > 0.

Proof: For x‚ÇÅ, x‚ÇÇ with x‚ÇÅ < x‚ÇÇ and Œª ‚àà [0,1] we have:

$$f(\lambda x_1 + (1-\lambda)x_2) = (\lambda x_1 + (1-\lambda)x_2)^3$$

$$\lambda f(x_1) + (1-\lambda)f(x_2) = \lambda x_1^3 + (1-\lambda)x_2^3$$

The difference is:

$$f(\lambda x_1 + (1-\lambda)x_2) - (\lambda f(x_1) + (1-\lambda)f(x_2)) = 3\lambda(1-\lambda)(x_2 - x_1)^2(\lambda x_1 + (1-\lambda)x_2)$$

This difference is positive for x > 0 and negative for x < 0.

5. Summary

Differential calculus is a fundamental tool in analysis with various applications.

Important Properties:

  • Definition of the derivative as a limit
  • Differentiation rules: sum, product, quotient, and chain rules
  • Higher derivatives
  • Applications: extrema, monotonicity, curvature

Applications:

  • Analysis: function investigation
  • Physics: velocity, acceleration
  • Engineering: optimization
